title: Isolation, cultivation, and application of primary respiratory epithelial cells obtained by nasal brushing, polyp samples, or lung explants
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Sampling procedure (∼1 h)
Critical: (Important to check before sampling) For non-cystic fibrosis participants, samples should be taken while participant does NOT have an acute infection (exacerbation).
Critical: (Important to check before sampling) For subjects with cystic fibrosis, if a pulmonary exacerbation is in progress, the sampling should be done by adding the additional antibiotic to culture media to avoid potential contamination.
Brush preparation and procedure (10 min).
Prepare 2 × 15 mL tubes with 2.5 mL of room temperature (18°C–23°C). PBS (or FertiCult) or take pre-prepared tubes out of fridge.
If using pre-prepared tubes, check the solution preparation date noted on the tube. The medium expires 3 months after the indicated date.
Label the tubes with the subject’s identification/reference number and the date of sampling, put aside.
Fill in the information sheet provided (see Data S1[href=https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1679-Mmc1.pdf]) with the subject’s identification number/tag, the genotype and if possible, information concerning the antibiotic resistance profiles of bacterial strains isolated from the subject.
Prepare the sampling equipment:
Sterilized nose speculum (can be sterilized with 70% ethanol or other approved sterilizing solution that is not harmful to humans).
Sterilized Politzer tweezers (tweezers are pre-sterilized; if these are not available, they can be sterilized with 70% ethanol or other approved sterilizing solution that is not harmful to humans).

Assemble 4 flat cotton meshes: these will be used to apply the local anesthetic to the nasal turbinate. Assemble two meshes approximately 5 cm and two meshes approximately 10 cm long (the longer ones will be used in the 2nd application, as they have to reach further back into the nostril area at the following point 3c). Roll the proximal end rolled into a cone, in order to introduce the mesh as far as possible up the subject’s nose (4 meshes in total per subject) (see Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1679-Fig2.jpg
Figure 2. Cotton meshes, politzer tweezers, and brush for sampling procedure
Ask the subject to clean/blow their nose. Ask them to sit comfortably in a chair. Explain to the subject that the procedure may cause eye watering, but this will quickly resolve.
Tilt the subject’s head backwards and examine the nostrils with the speculum to:
Identify the inferior turbinate (Figures 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3] and 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig7]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1679-Fig3.jpg
Figure 3. Identification of the inferior turbinate
Remove the speculum.
Preparation of nasal cotton meshes for administration of local anesthesia (5 min).
Soak the four strands of cotton in xylocaine 5% with naphazoline solution (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1679-Fig4.jpg
Figure 4. Soaking of cotton mesh in xylocaine 5% with naphazoline solution
Squeeze off any excess liquid from the cotton meshes to prevent liquid dropping into the posterior pharynx to avoid unnecessary anesthesia of pharynx. Roll the end to be introduced into the nostril first (Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1679-Fig5.jpg
Figure 5. Preparation of cotton meshes for insertion into nostrils
Applying anesthetic (15 min):
Tilt subject’s head backwards and introduce one cotton mesh (one of the 5 cm meshes) per nostril with a horizontal movement, using the Politzer tweezers. The aim is to anesthetize the proximal entry points of the nostrils (see Figure 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6]A).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1679-Fig6.jpg

Figure 6. Placement of cotton mesh and nasal brush
(A and B) Introducing (A) the cotton mesh into the nostril and (B) introducing the nasal brush into the nostril.
Leave in situ for 5 min.
Remove these cotton meshes and take the second set of meshes which are a little longer (approx. 10 cm), as they need to reach further back into the nostril area.
Introduce one cotton mesh per nostril with a horizontal movement, using the Politzer tweezers. Take advantage of the anesthesia introduced by the first mesh insertions (now removed) to push the cotton in as far as possible.
Leave in situ for at least 10 min.
Remove cotton meshes.
Ask the subject to blow their nose once more.
Nasal brushing technique: (10 min).
Wet the nasal brush with sterile PBS (or sterile FertiCult) in a 15 mL conical tube.
Introduce the nasal brush by orienting the movement horizontally i.e., having located/visualized the inferior turbinate, angle the brush horizontally along the passage between the inferior and middle turbinate, in a horizontal direction (see Figures 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6]B and 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig7] and Methods video S1[href=https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1679-Mmc1.pdf]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1679-Fig7.jpg
Figure 7. Locating the inferior turbinate: 1st and 2nd mesh localization and area to brush
    Your browser does not support HTML5 video.
  
Methods Video S1. Nasal brushing technique, related to step 4
The brushing should take place at the lower turbinate in the middle third (the anterior third is covered with non-ciliated epithelium).
Brush with five to ten rotational and linear movements.
Note: The subject may feel a localized tingling sensation in their nostrils and the brushing will probably cause some eye watering, but this discomfort will pass rapidly.
Remove the brush from the nostril.

Place the brush in tube with sterile PBS (or in the 2nd 15 mL tube with FertiCult if being sent to an alternative institution for testing) and shake the brush vigorously in the medium for 15 s.
If an endoscopy brush is used, it is possible to “sweep/scrape” the brush using the plastic sheath. Normally one should see mucosal fragments floating in the solution.
At a minimum, obtain one brushing per nostril. Ideally, brush each nostril twice, if possible (the same brush can be used for subsequent brushings of the same nostril).
When the last brushing has been completed, shake the brush in the labeled tube and leave it inside. Cut the remaining wire if needed to allow the brush to fit entirely into the tube. Seal the labeled tube and set aside (preferably on ice or in the fridge).
Repeat the procedure with the other nostril.
If the tube containing FertiCult was used and the sample is meant to be sent to another center, add 0.1 mL of antibiotic solution to each of the labeled tubes containing the samples (using a sterile procedure, if possible).
The labeled tubes with PBS are now ready for culture (and the labeled tubes with FertiCult for shipping). Deliver biological material to the laboratory as soon as possible, preferably on wet ice. If the brushes are kept in the Ferticult, the tubes can be transported at room temperature (18°C–23°C) within a 48-h time window.
Preparation of the sample before expansion: (30 min). After collection of the samples from the subject, the preparatory steps are as follows:
Try to remove as many cells as possible from the brush. One can use the sheath from the wire, on which the brush is attached, to isolate the cells. Once cells are removed, the brush can be discarded.

Centrifuge the content of the tubes at 500 × g, 5 min, and 4°C.
Gently aspirate the supernatant avoiding touching the pellet and discard the liquid.
Add 0.5 mL of Trypsin (see materials and equipment[href=https://www.wicell.org#materials-and-equipment]: Aliquots), resuspend the cells, and leave for 5–7 min in the incubator at 37°C.
Add 1 mL of amplification medium (see materials and equipment[href=https://www.wicell.org#materials-and-equipment] for preparation) to stop the enzymatic process. Combine the content of the two tubes and mix gently.
Centrifuge at 500 × g for 5 min at 4°C. Aspirate and discard the supernatant and gently resuspend the pellet in the 1 mL of amplification medium.
Evenly distribute the cell suspension into collagen-coated flasks (see materials and equipment[href=https://www.wicell.org#materials-and-equipment] for preparation) containing:
10 mL of amplification medium (75 cm2 flask).
5 mL of amplification medium (25 cm2 flask).
Note: This step defines Passage 0 of the cell culture.
Put the flask into the incubator at 37°C until the following day. In the most optimal conditions, it is advisable to check cells 24 h after culture initiation, allow a minimum of 12 h for the cell adhesion.
Note: Amplification of the cells usually takes between 3–5 days after starting the culture, if the proliferation of the cells takes longer than a week, there is a risk that the cells will not grow successfully.
Note: As a rule, a standard brush procedure (2 brushings per nostril and the 2 nostrils sampled) will allow one 75 cm2 flask to be seeded.
A brushing of a single nostril can be seeded in one 25 cm2 flask.

Lung Explant Samples (2 days: Day 1: 1–1.5 h). Lung explant samples (from normal or diseased lungs) are surgically supplied; it is not the remit of this manuscript to provide detailed guidance on sampling of lung explants. Briefly, bronchi after lobectomy or pneumonectomy or samples taken during lung transplantation are the sources of bronchial endothelial cells. The lung specimens are transported to the laboratory in a container filled with the PBS or culture medium, on wet ice. The lung explants should be delivered to the laboratory as soon as possible, ideally within 24 h.
Note: Thaw the Pronase and prepare the medium in advance (see materials and equipment[href=https://www.wicell.org#materials-and-equipment], Dissociation Media).
Pronase is a commercially available mixture of proteases, used to help dissociate cells.
After receiving the lung explant, the whole lung explant sample, including the transport media should be added (see materials and equipment[href=https://www.wicell.org#materials-and-equipment]: Transport medium) into the 10 cm Petri dish (all procedures to be conducted in sterile conditions).
Use a scalpel blade (for this procedure, a disposable lab scalpel blade can be used with a plastic handle or as an alternative, disposable stainless-steel lancets individually foil wrapped) to remove and discard the necrotic parts of the bronchi and put the cleaned piece of the bronchi into the empty 50 mL tube (see Figures 8[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig8], 9[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig9], and 10[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig10]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1679-Fig8.jpg
Figure 8. Equipment and lung explant preparation
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1679-Fig9.jpg
Figure 9. Lung explant
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1679-Fig10.jpg
Figure 10. Recovery of cells from the lumen of the explant
Wash the bronchi twice to remove blood cells:
Add 25 mL of PBS-DTT-FTVC (at room temperature: 18°C–23°C) to the bronchi and shake manually for 30 s.
Aspirate media.
Repeat steps i. and ii.
Note: DDT solution helps to remove mucus excess and lower the potential bacterial impact on contamination of the sample.

Rinse the bronchi to remove the DTT:
Add 25 mL of PBS-FTVC to the bronchi and shake for 30 s.
Aspirate media.
Repeat steps i. and ii.
Note: The used antibiotic mix F: Fungizone, T: Tazocillin, V: Vancomycin and C: Colomycin has the purpose of preventing possible contamination of the culture with bacteria, fungi or yeast. Thus, early exposure of the human tissue to the antibiotics is of great importance.
After repeated step ii., fill the tube containing the explant with 14 mL of the pre-prepared DMEM/F12-FTVC medium (from the 50 mL tube, see materials and equipment[href=https://www.wicell.org#materials-and-equipment]: Dissociation Media), to prevent the bronchi from drying out.
Dissociation of the airway epithelial cells:
Add 4 mL of Pronase to the 50 mL tube containing now only 36 mL of DMEM/F12-FTVC.
Aspirate the 14 mL of medium from step d.
Transfer the bronchi into the DMEM/F12-FTVC-Pronase solution.
Incubate the bronchi over night at 4°C on a rotator (12 h for best results, possible minimal time of 4 h at 10–20 rpm - if it is possible to adjust it, as there may only be one speed set by default).
Pause point: NEXT DAY (Day 2: task will take approximately 1–1.5 h).
Centrifuge the 50 mL tube containing the bronchi: 500 × g, 5 min, and 4°C.
Gently aspirate the supernatant, leaving 20 mL in the tube. Do not discard that 20 mL but pass it through the autoclaved stainless strainer at 100 μm pore size minimum to the 50 mL container/tube.
Add 20 mL of DMEM/F12-FBS20%-FTVC medium to neutralize the remaining Pronase.
Shake to mix well, then vortex for 2 min.
Put the content of the tube (bronchi and medium) into a 15 cm Petri dish.
Then bisect the lung explant with the sterile scalpel.

Recover cells from the inside (lumen side) of the explant using the scalpel blade to scrape them off.
Rinse the scalpel and the bronchi with DMEM/F12-FBS20%-FTVC from the petri dish to recover as many cells as possible: try to rinse the bronchi with the fast flow of the medium from the pipette.
Repeat rinsing twice.
Aspirate the medium containing cells, and transfer to the 50 mL container/ tube through the stainless-steel strainer.
Rinse the Petri dish again with the remaining DMEM/F12-FBS20%-FTVC; recover the medium too, as indicated in the above point.
Centrifuge the whole content of the recovered medium cell solution in the fresh 50 mL tube at 500 × g, 5 min, and 4°C.
Note: Depending on the quantity of the recovered cell solution, it may need to be distributed between 2 × 50 mL tubes.
Gently aspirate and discard the supernatant.
Add trypsin: the amount added to the cell will depend on the pellet size as indicated in Figure 11[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig11]. Between 1 to 5 mL of trypsin can be added to dislodge cells, the bigger volume of the trypsin the more carefully the incubation time should be monitored. Resuspend the cells by gently pipetting up and down, and incubate for 7 min at 37°C.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1679-Fig11.jpg
Figure 11. Example of the pellet to which 5 mL of medium should be added
Add up to 5 mL of DMEM/F12-FBS20%-FTVC and mix the cells by gentle pipetting.
Centrifuge 500 × g, 4°C, and 5 min.
Aspirate and discard the supernatant:
Add amplification media depending on the size of the pellet it will be between 2 and 5 mL and resuspend well with the pipette.
Place 15 μL of the cell suspension on a counting chamber and count the cells.

Add 10 mL amplification medium to a collagen-coated 75 cm2 flask (see step 9: Note, for use of the counting chamber or haemocytometer), and seed 500,000 cells per 75 cm2 flask.
Put the flasks into the incubator, at 37°C.
Note: This step defines passage 0 of the cultured cells (the first seeding of the cells after isolation).
Note: Many of the lung specimens from diseased tissues may carry multidrug-resistant pathogens, it is therefore essential to add to the culture media specific antibiotics if the patient’s antibiogram is known.
Polyp Samples (2 days: Day 1: 1 h). Polyp samples may be obtained from the surgical intervention known as a polypectomy. This surgical procedure can be offered to patients with isolated or syndromic nasal sinus polyposis, resistant to medical treatment and who present as symptomatic with nasal obstruction, smell disorder, chronic rhinorrhea, or repeated sinus infections. Specimens obtained from patients without cystic fibrosis are used as Wild Type (WT). The polypectomy is often associated with the opening of the sinuses. It is an endoscopic intervention, that is, through the nasal cavity with a camera. It is performed under general anesthesia. The patient leaves the evening or the day after the operation. The polyps are then transported in sterile PBS or culture medium in the 50 mL tube on wet ice.
Thaw the Pronase and prepare the dissociation media in advance (see materials and equipment[href=https://www.wicell.org#materials-and-equipment]).
Aspirate transport medium (be careful to not aspirate small polyps).
Place the polyp in an empty 50 mL falcon tube.
Wash the polyp to eliminate blood cells:
Add 25 mL of PBS-DTT to the polyp and shake manually for 1 min.
Aspirate medium.
Repeat the steps i. and ii.
Note: DDT solution helps to remove excess mucus and lower the potential bacterial impact on contamination of the sample.

Rinse the polyp to remove the DTT:
Add 25 mL of PBS-FTVC to the polyp and shake for 1 min.
Aspirate medium.
Repeat the steps i. and ii.
Note: The used antibiotic mix F: Fungizone, T: Tazocillin, V: Vancomycin and C: Colomycin has the purpose of preventing possible contamination of the culture with bacteria, fungi or yeast. Thus, starting the exposure of the human tissue to the antibiotics at the earliest stage is of great importance.
From the 50 mL tube with the ready medium DMEM/F12-FTVC take 14 mL and add it to polyp, it will prevent the polyp from drying out.
Dissociation of the airway epithelial cells (see Figure 12[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig12]):
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1679-Fig12.jpg
Figure 12. Dissociation of the airway epithelial cells from the polyp
In the 50 mL tube containing 36 mL of DMEM/F12-FTVC add 4 mL of Pronase.
Aspirate the 14 mL of medium (from step e: iv. above).
Transfer the polyp into the DMEM/F12-FTVC-Pronase solution.
Incubate the polyp overnight (12 h minimum) at 4°C on a rotator, at 10–20 rpm if it is possible to adjust it, as sometimes there is only one speed set by default.
Note the time when the polyp is placed in the Pronase solution.
Pause point: NEXT DAY (Day 2: 1 h).
Centrifuge the tube containing the polyp at 500 × g, 5 min, and 4°C.
Gently aspirate the supernatant, leaving 20 mL in the tube.
Add 20 mL of DMEM/F12-FBS20%-FTVC medium to neutralize the remaining Pronase.
Shake to mix well, then vortex for 2 min, at half-speed.
Pass the content (polyp and medium) into a 15 cm Petri dish through a previously autoclaved stainless-steel strainer.
Note: keep the 50 mL tube.
There is no need to scratch the polyp because the cells are more easily detached than in the lung explant samples.

Rinse with 5 mL of DMEM/F12-FBS20%-FTVC, one should try to rinse the polyp with the fast flow of the medium from the pipette:
Repeat the previous step (step m) twice.
Aspirate the medium containing cells, and transfer to the initial 50 mL Falcon tube, through the stainless-steel strainer.
Rinse the Petri dish again with DMEM/F12-FBS20%-FTVC; recover the medium too, as indicated in step m ii above.
Centrifuge the whole content at 1,500 rpm, 5 min, and 4°C.
Gently aspirate the supernatant.
Add between 1 to 2 mL of trypsin, (adding 2 mL if required for larger pellet size). Resuspend the cells and leave for 7 min at 37°C.
Add 5 mL of DMEM/F12-FBS20%-FTVC and gently resuspend by pipetting.
Centrifuge at 500 × g, 4°C, 5 min.
Aspirate the supernatant.
Add amplification medium (materials and equipment[href=https://www.wicell.org#materials-and-equipment]) (depending on the size of the pellet add between 1 and 4 mL) and resuspend the pellet with the pipette.
Place 15 μL of the cell suspension on a counting chamber and count the cells.
Put 500,000 cells per 75 cm2 flask, which is filled with 10 mL of amplification medium.
Put the flasks into the incubator until next day.
This step defines passage 0 of the cultured cells (the first seeding of cells after isolation).
Note: Do not forget that antibiotics are being adjusted according to the subject’s antibiogram, if no information is available; add antibiotics indicated as a ‘standard’ in the protocol.
Expansion (3–5 days). From the expansion stage in the flasks, the following steps are common regardless of the initial origin of the cell (brushing/explant/polyp).
The day after seeding and only on that day: (Depending on number of flasks it will take from 30 min to a few hours).
Aspirate medium from the 75 cm2 or 25 cm2 flask.

Rinse with 10 mL of PBS-FTVC.
Aspirate PBS-FTVC.
Add fresh 10 mL (for a T75 flask) or 5 mL (for a T25 flask) of amplification medium.
Inspect the cells every day for:
Adherence (clumps of cells that did not attach to the culture vessel).
Shape (the epithelial cells are columnar and non-ciliated, when stretched on a culture dish: with large cytoplasm and one nucleus) (see Figure 13[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig13]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1679-Fig13.jpg
Figure 13. Cell expansion
(A) Cell suspension.
(B) Cells after 1 day in culture.
(C) Cells after 3 days in culture (60% of confluence).
Growth (cells should slowly increase in quantity and grow across the plastic surface).
Quality of the medium (it should be clear of pieces of cells or their floating aggregates).
Change the medium every 48–72 h: standard procedure.
Aspirate medium.
Add fresh 10 mL (for a T75 flask) or 5 mL (for a T25 flask) of amplification medium.
Note: The expansion can take from 3 to 5 days depending on cell number (See Figure 13[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig13]C).
The cells are ready to be passaged when they reach 80%–90% of confluence (only small holes in the cells monolayer are visible). If it the expansion of the cells takes longer, i.e., more than 10 days, the culture might not be successful.
If medium is not clear (i.e., cloudy), this could indicate a bacterial or yeast infection in the medium, in which case:
Sample the medium and send the aliquots to the microbiology department for bacterial analysis (to assess if bacterial contamination is from the patient or from laboratory contamination).
Rinse the cells in the flask with 10 mL of adapted PBS-FTVC.
Add 10 mL of amplification medium with antibiotics indicated in the antibiogram (if available).
In the event of an absence of antibiotic information specific for the patient, add Ciprofloxacin (materials and equipment[href=https://www.wicell.org#materials-and-equipment]).

Note: Avoid aminoglycoside antibiotics, especially for cells cultured from subjects with codon stop mutations in the CFTR gene.
Notify the lab manager about possible contamination of medium and incubator and follow laboratory procedures for disinfection and isolation of exposed flasks.
Freezing.
A portion of the expanded cells after the first passage should be frozen for bio banking; ideally, 0.5–1.0 × 106 cells should be frozen per cryovial (according to the following step 13).
In case of an insufficient number of cells, freezing can be performed with the cells from passage 1 (P1).
Regarding rare and interesting genotypes, the cells should be frozen also at P1 and P2.
General guidelines:
Never seed cells directly onto filters after sampling: the expansion phase is needed.
In the incubator, try to separate WT and CF cultures, for example placing the clearly labeled WT cultures on a separate, clearly labeled shelf.
If contamination is suspected in some flasks, change medium in these flasks at the end of cell culture handling.
Seeding cells onto filters: (Depending on number of flasks from 1 h to few hours). First, discuss the number of filters needed, with members of the laboratory staff: unseeded cells will be further propagated if the passage of the expansion is lower than P2 or frozen.
Pre-coat filters with collagen as shown in materials and equipment[href=https://www.wicell.org#materials-and-equipment].
Aspirate and discard culture medium from 75 cm2 culture flask/s.
Add 10 mL of PBS to cell culture flask.
Aspirate and discard PBS.
Add 2 mL of Trypsin (see materials and equipment[href=https://www.wicell.org#materials-and-equipment]) for a 75 cm2 flask, and leave for 7 min at 37°C.
Tap the flask firmly, with the palm of the hand, to help the cells detach. One should keep the flask in a horizontal position to avoid spreading the suspension.

Add 10 mL of amplification medium to stop the enzymatic reaction. Vigorously rinse the flask, using the 10 mL pipette to draw up and expel the amplification medium over the flask surface to rinse and detach cells.
Note: Check the trypsinized flask under the microscope. If there are still many cells attached to the flask surface, repeat the trypsinization, by adding 2 mL trypsin and incubating at 37°C for 5 min maximum.
Transfer the cell suspension to a 50 mL tube and centrifuge at 500 × g, 5 min, and 4°C.
Aspirate and discard the supernatant.
Add 3–5 mL of amplification medium depending on the size of the pellet, resuspend pellet with the 10 mL pipette.
Take 15 μL of the cell suspension, place on a cell-counting chamber, count and calculate cell density of suspension.
Note: In this SOP, the Malassez counting chamber is used. Different counting chambers may be used in different laboratories such as Bürker Türk, Neubauer-improved or haemocytometer but the spacing of the grid and volume of the chamber must be known.
Note: Count the number of cells in 10 small squares (as shown in Figure 14[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig14]) (Stokes et al., 2014[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib7]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1679-Fig14.jpg
Figure 14. Counting cells
To calculate the previously defined volume on the apical side of the filter follow the technical counting note as follows:
Total number of cells = number of counted cells × 104 × volume in mL of the medium in which the cells were suspended in the tube.
Number of filters feasible to prepare = Total number of cells ÷ Number of cells per filter.
Minimum 330,000 cells for a filter size of 0.33 cm2, up to 350,000 cells / filter.

Volume of the cell suspension to be put on apical side of the filter = volume in mL of the medium in which the cells were suspended in the tube (quantity used in step j above) ÷ Number of filter feasible to prepare.
The maximal apical volume is 300 μL, if the calculated volume is smaller than that; one should complete it up to 300 μL with amplification medium (before adding the cells).
The volume of basal medium is 900 μL.
Prepare a 24-well plate with the desired number of collagen-coated filters.
Maintenance of filters before air-liquid (ALI) interface. (Depending on number of filter plates from 30 min to few hours).
The apical medium is not removed before day 2–3. If the apical medium is left for longer (up to 5 days until the cells fill up the filter area), exchange it for fresh 300 μL of the amplification medium.
The basal medium is changed every 48–72 h. Aspirate and discard basal medium and add 900 μL of fresh ALI medium.
If medium is not clear (i.e., cloudy), and there is suspicion of contamination, collect the medium and send it to the bacteriology department for testing.
If the apical medium appears cloudy before starting ALI culture: Aspirate and discard the apical medium. Rinse with 300 μL of adapted PBS-FTVC. Add fresh 300 μL of amplification medium with change of antibiotics according to the antibiogram.
ALI can be initiated 2–5 days after cells are seeded onto the filters.
From now on, always use different pipette tips for changing the medium on the apical and basal sides of the filter (to avoid cross-contamination).
Initiation of ALI phase (change basal medium every 48–72 h).
Aspirate and discard the apical medium. From now onwards, the apical side remains medium-free.
Aspirate and discard basal medium.

Add 900 μL of fresh ALI medium in basal part of well.
Change the basal medium every 48–72 h.
Cell differentiation will now take between 15 to 30 days (from start of air-liquid phase) to the point of mature epithelium.
Note: Poor quality of the filter is suspected if the ALI medium starts to pass over onto the apical side of the filter (this may happen around 7 days after launching the ALI culture).
After about 2 weeks at the ALI, cells start to differentiate, and cilia appear.
It is very important to remove CIPROFLOXACIN and AMINOGLYCOSIDE ANTIBIOTICS from the culture medium 5 days before planned.
Measurement of the transepithelial electrical resistance (TEER) (30 min). This is recommended to prepare the filters for use in different assays. This method allows verification of the integrity of the tight junctions in the monolayer of epithelial cells and is carried out without damage to the cells (Srinivasan et al., 2015[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib6]). (The EVOM2 can be used, the most widely used manual epithelial volt/ohm meter). Whilst this procedure is not the remit of this protocol, a brief outline is provided below. For more detailed procedural instructions, please refer to the manufacturer’s instructions. (See Figure 15[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig15]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1679-Fig15.jpg
Figure 15. Measurement of the transepithelial electrical resistance (TEER)
For resistance measurements (according to the manufacturer manual):
Turn the Power on, on the EVOM2.
Sterilize the electrode with 70% ethanol (submerge the electrodes for several seconds) and air dry.
Connect the electrode to the meter.
Set the Function switch to Ohms.
Turn the Mode Switch to R.
Turn the range switch to 20k (kΩ, ×1000 = Ω).
Measure the blank resistance and record the value (R blank).

The short electrode should be placed in the insert (apical compartment), the longer arm of the electrode is located in the basolateral compartment.
All movement should be performed gently to avoid damage of the cell monolayer.
Push the measure R button.
Record the given number which will be expressed in kΩ.
Measure the sample (R sample) in the same manner. It is advisable to perform the measurements in duplicates.
Perform the measurements in rather fast pace as the temperature may impact the results (one method to minimize temperature-induced variability in TEER measurements between samples is to place the culture plate on a pre-warmed 37°C heat block during measurements).
To obtain the reading: (R (sample) Ω - R (blank) Ω) × 0.33 cm2 (membrane area).
Clean, dry and store the electrode.
Note: If evaluation of epithelia by TEER is conducted when the cells are already under ALI conditions, sterile physiological saline solution should be added on the apical side to allow electrical contact with the electrode. A volume of solution sufficient to allow insertion of the apical electrode should be used (∼100 μL). After measurement, the saline solution must be removed to return to ALI condition.
For further guidance, please refer to: https://www.wpiinc.com/media/wysiwyg/pdf/EVOM2_IM.pdf[href=https://www.wpiinc.com/media/wysiwyg/pdf/EVOM2_IM.pdf] (the meter models may differ).
Freezing cells (Depending on number of flasks from 30 min to 1.5 h).
Prepare freezing medium (see materials and equipment[href=https://www.wicell.org#materials-and-equipment]).
Prepare cryotubes with the name of the subject/identification number (as per local site policy), site ID, the type of cells, passage number, date of freezing, initials of the person performing the freezing and if possible, the number of frozen cells.
Freeze cells at P0 and at no higher than P2.
Choose a 75 cm2 flask of cells (P0-P2) at 80%–90% confluence.
Aspirate and discard the medium from the flask.

Add 10 mL of PBS.
Remove the PBS (the purpose of steps f and g is to remove residual medium from the flask).
Add 2 mL of trypsin and put into incubator for 7 min.
Tap the flask, with the palm of your hand, to help the cells detach. One should keep the flask in a horizontal position to avoid spreading the suspension.
To stop the trypsin activity, add 10 mL of amplification medium.
Rinse the cell-growing surface well.
Repeat the process several times trying to produce a strong flow in order to detach as many cells as possible.
Transfer the cell suspension to a 50 mL tube.
Centrifuge at 500 × g, 4°C, and 5 min.
Remove the supernatant. Resuspend the cell pellet in a sufficient (refer to the pellet size) amount of the regular medium. Count the cells and spin the whole content of the tube.
In each cryovial, freeze around 1–2 × 106 cells per 1 mL of freezing medium.
Resuspend the cells in the desired amount of freezing medium. Re-distribute equal amounts of cell suspension to each cryotube.
Place the cryovials in Mr. Frosty (Nalgene) and put into a −80°C freezer.
The next day, move the preserved sample to the nitrogen storage container, where the cells can be kept for many years.
Defrosting (30 min).
Prepare the materials needed:
Warm up the water bath to 37°C.
Prepare the amplification medium.
Warm up the medium to 37°C.
15 mL tube(s) and 75 cm2 flask(s).
Remove cryovials from the nitrogen storage tank.
Leave the cryotube for a few minutes in the water bath (up to 2 min), taking care not to submerge the whole vial in the water.
Note the label on the vial before wiping it with alcohol, to avoid losing the information from the cryotube.

Using a 1 mL pipette, transfer the defrosted cells to the empty 15 mL tube.
In a drop-wise manner, add 1 mL of the warm amplification medium.
After one minute, again add 1 mL of amplification medium and wait an additional minute.
Next fill the tube with 10 mL of amplification medium and centrifuge for 2 min at 230 × g.
Aspirate and discard the supernatant.
Check what number of frozen cells is indicated on the cryovial. Resuspend the cell pellet in the volume of amplification medium required to achieve, at least, a cell density of 1 × 106 cells/mL.
Put the cell suspension into the flask(s) containing a sufficient amount of the medium, as follows:
75 cm2 flask: seed up to 2 million cells to a total volume of 10 mL amplification medium.
150 cm2 flask, seed up to 4 million cells to a total volume of 15 mL amplification medium.
Place the flasks in the 37°C incubator and observe cell expansion over the course of the next 2–3 days.
END OF PROCEDURE.
